#Text=CHAPTER XXIX .
#Text=KATE WRITES A LETTER
#Text=Bertram feared that he knew , before the portrait was hung , that it was a failure .
#Text=He was sure that he knew it on the evening of the twentieth when he encountered the swiftly averted eyes of some of his artist friends , and saw the perplexed frown on the faces of others .
#Text=But he knew , afterwards , that he did not really know it -- till he read the newspapers during the next few days .
#Text=There was praise -- oh , yes ; the faint praise that kills .
#Text=There was some adverse criticism , too ; but it was of the light , insincere variety that is given to mediocre work by unimportant artists .
#Text=Then , here and there , appeared the signed critiques of the men whose opinion counted -- and Bertram knew that he had failed .
#Text=Neither as a work of art , nor as a likeness , was the portrait the success that Henshaw 's former work would seem to indicate that it should have been .

#Text=Indeed , as one caustic pen put it , if this were to be taken as a sample of what was to follow -- then the famous originator of “ The Face of a Girl ” had “ a most distinguished future behind him . ”
#Text=Seldom , if ever before , had an exhibited portrait attracted so much attention .

#Text=As Bertram had said , uncounted eyes were watching for it before it was hung , because it was a portrait of the noted beauty , Marguerite Winthrop , and because two other well-known artists had failed where he , Bertram Henshaw , was hoping to succeed .

#Text=After it was hung , and the uncounted eyes had seen it -- either literally , or through the eyes of the critics -- interest seemed rather to grow than to lessen , for other uncounted eyes wanted to see what all the fuss was about , anyway .
#Text=And when these eyes had seen , their owners talked .
#Text=Nor did they , by any means , all talk against the portrait .
#Text=Some were as loud in its praise as were others in its condemnation ; all of which , of course , but helped to attract more eyes to the cause of it all .
#Text=For Bertram and his friends these days were , naturally , trying ones .
#Text=William finally dreaded to open his newspaper .

#Text=( It had become the fashion , when murders and divorces were scarce , occasionally to “ feature ” somebody 's opinion of the Henshaw portrait , on the first page -- something that had almost never been known to happen before . ) Cyril , according to Marie , played “ perfectly awful things on his piano every day , now . ” Aunt Hannah had said “ Oh , my grief and conscience ! ” so many times that it melted now into a wordless groan whenever a new unfriendly criticism of the portrait met her indignant eyes .
#Text=Of all Bertram 's friends , Billy , perhaps not unnaturally , was the angriest .
#Text=Not only did she , after a time , refuse to read the papers , but she refused even to allow certain ones to be brought into the house , foolish and unreasonable as she knew this to be .

#Text=As to the artist himself , Bertram 's face showed drawn lines and his eyes sombre shadows , but his words and manner carried a stolid indifference that to Billy was at once heartbreaking and maddening .
#Text=“ But , Bertram , why do n't you do something ?
#Text=Why do n't you say something ?
#Text=Why do n't you act something ? ” she burst out one day .
#Text=The artist shrugged his shoulders .
#Text=“ But , my dear , what can I say , or do , or act ? ” he asked .
#Text=“ I do n't know , of course , ” sighed Billy .
#Text=“ But I know what I 'd like to do .
#Text=I should like to go out and -- fight somebody ! ”
#Text=So fierce were words and manner , coupled as they were with a pair of gentle eyes ablaze and two soft little hands doubled into menacing fists , that Bertram laughed .
#Text=“ What a fiery little champion it is , to be sure , ” he said tenderly .
#Text=“ But as if fighting could do any good -- in this case ! ”
#Text=Billy 's tense muscles relaxed .
#Text=Her eyes filled with tears .
#Text=“ No , I do n't suppose it would , ” she choked , beginning to cry , so that Bertram had to turn comforter .
#Text=“ Come , come , dear , ” he begged ;
#Text=“ do n't take it so to heart .
#Text=It 's not so bad , after all .
#Text=I 've still my good right hand left , and we 'll hope there 's something in it yet -- that 'll be worth while . ”
#Text=“ But this one is n't bad , ” stormed Billy .
#Text=“ It 's splendid ! I 'm sure , I think it 's a b-beautiful portrait , and I do n't see what people mean by talking so about it ! ”
#Text=Bertram shook his head .
#Text=His eyes grew sombre again .
#Text=“ Thank you , dear .
#Text=But I know -- and you know , really -- that it is n't a splendid portrait .
#Text=I 've done lots better work than that . ”
#Text=“ Then why do n't they look at those , and let this alone ? ” wailed Billy , with indignation .
#Text=“ Because I deliberately put up this for them to see , ” smiled the artist , wearily .
#Text=Billy sighed , and twisted in her chair .
#Text=“ What does -- Mr .
#Text=Winthrop say ? ” she asked at last , in a faint voice .
#Text=Bertram lifted his head .
#Text=“ Mr. Winthrop 's been a trump all through , dear .
#Text=He 's already insisted on paying for this -- and he 's ordered another . ”
#Text=“ Another ! ”
#Text=“ Yes .
#Text=The old fellow never minces his words , as you may know .
#Text=He came to me one day , put his hand on my shoulder , and said tersely :
#Text=' Will you give me another , same terms ?
#Text=Go in , boy , and win . Show ' em !
#Text=I lost the first ten thousand I made .
#Text=I did n't the next ! '
#Text=That 's all he said .
#Text=Before I could even choke out an answer he was gone .
#Text=Gorry ! talk about his having a ' heart of stone ' !
#Text=I do n't believe another man in the country would have done that -- and done it in the way he did -- in the face of all this talk , ” finished Bertram , his eyes luminous with feeling .
